predictions.text: The current U.S. federal government shutdown that began in early February 2026 will end (a funding law is enacted and OMB/OPM announce reopening) by 2026-02-04 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if by the deadline Congress passes and the President signs a CR/appropriations law restoring funding and major agencies publicly confirm reopening/normal operations; otherwise NO.
evidence: Speaker Johnson said he’s confident the shutdown will end by Tuesday (CNBC, 2026-02-01): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/01/government-shutdown-mike-johnson.html
monitoring_signals: House/Senate vote schedule for CR/omnibus
White House signing statement / bill enactment notice
OPM/OMB and major agency reopening notices
CBO/appropriations trackers and congressional leadership statements
predictions.rationale: Leadership signaling and political pressure typically accelerate short shutdown resolutions; Tuesday-specific guidance makes a near-term end more likely than not.

predictions.text: Oracle will publicly price and close new debt financing in 2026 totaling at least $20.0 billion (USD) gross proceeds (aggregate across one or more offerings) to fund AI/data-center expansion by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Oracle (or underwriters) announce priced bond(s)/notes/convertibles in 2026 and disclosed gross proceeds sum to >=$20.0B by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: Oracle plans to raise up to $50B this year to fund AI expansion (MarketWatch, 2026-02-01): https://www.marketwatch.com/story/oracle-amps-up-its-ai-bet-with-a-plan-to-raise-as-much-as-50-billion-this-year-872a2dba
monitoring_signals: Oracle 8-Ks, press releases, and earnings call commentary on financing
Investment bank syndicate/pricing press releases and term sheets
Credit rating agency actions (Moody’s/S&P/Fitch) tied to new issuance
Bond market calendars (Bloomberg/Refinitiv new issue feeds)
predictions.rationale: Management’s stated fundraising ambition and capex needs make sizable issuance plausible, but scale/timing depend on market conditions and alternative funding routes.

predictions.text: CISA will publish an alert/advisory (AA/MAR/ICS/other) explicitly referencing the Notepad++ distribution/update-channel hijack (or 'Notepad++' compromise) with mitigation guidance by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if cisa.gov publishes an official alert/advisory that names Notepad++ and describes the hijack/compromise plus recommended mitigations by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: Notepad++ reported its distribution was hijacked by state-sponsored actors (Notepad++ incident update): https://notepad-plus-plus.org/news/hijacked-incident-info-update/
monitoring_signals: CISA news/alerts RSS and GitHub advisories referencing Notepad++
US-CERT/CISA social posts about supply-chain compromises
Vendor follow-up incident reports and IoCs
Downstream EDR/AV detections and threat-intel writeups
predictions.rationale: High-profile supply-chain compromises often trigger CISA dissemination of mitigations/IoCs, but CISA may defer to vendor and private-sector reporting.

predictions.text: CME Group will increase initial margin requirements by at least 10% for at least one of its gold or silver futures contracts (COMEX) due to volatility, effective by 2026-02-28 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if CME publishes a margin advisory showing an initial margin hike of >=10% versus the immediately prior level for GC/SI (or related main contract) effective by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: Gold and silver experienced a historic plunge with elevated volatility (CNBC, 2026-02-02): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/02/gold-silver-sell-off-historic-plunge-.html
monitoring_signals: CME margin circulars/advisories for GC and SI
Implied volatility and intraday range spikes in metals
Clearing member communications on risk add-ons
Open interest/liquidity stress indicators
predictions.rationale: Large spot moves frequently lead to margin adjustments, but CME may wait for volatility to persist and clearinghouse risk metrics to breach thresholds.

predictions.text: At least one automaker or battery manufacturer will announce a cancellation, indefinite pause, or delay of at least 6 months for a previously announced EV/battery manufacturing project located in the U.S. South (AL, GA, KY, MS, NC, SC, TN, TX) by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a company press release/SEC filing/government statement confirms cancellation/pause or schedule slip >=6 months for a named EV/battery plant in the listed states by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: EV demand pullback is hitting Southern U.S. factories and jobs (CNBC, 2026-02-01): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/01/ev-pullback-factories-jobs-south.html
monitoring_signals: Company capex revisions and earnings call remarks on EV capacity
State/local incentive renegotiations or clawback notices
Construction permitting/workforce hiring slowdowns
Battery supply contract deferrals and equipment order cancellations
predictions.rationale: Demand uncertainty and cost pressures often force schedule resets; however, political incentives and sunk costs can keep projects moving despite softer demand.

predictions.text: AstraZeneca will begin trading on the NYSE as a primary listing (not only OTC/ADR continuation) following a public company announcement and exchange confirmation, by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if NYSE and AstraZeneca publicly confirm listing and AZN begins NYSE trading as a primary listing by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: AstraZeneca will list in New York while investing heavily in China (CNBC, 2026-02-01): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/01/astrazeneca-nyse-listing-china-pharma-pours-15-billion-into-china.html
monitoring_signals: AstraZeneca press releases on listing process/timeline
NYSE listing notices and ticker status updates
Regulatory filings related to listing structure
Investor relations presentations confirming listing mechanics
predictions.rationale: Company-stated intent suggests follow-through is likely, but legal/structural decisions and market timing can slip.

predictions.text: The Government of India will publish an official Gazette notification or equivalent statutory instrument implementing a zero-tax (or tax-holiday) regime specifically targeting AI compute/data-center workloads, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if an official Indian government publication (Gazette/Ministry notification) establishes a tax exemption/holiday explicitly tied to AI workloads/data centers as described by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: India offered zero taxes through 2047 to attract global AI workloads (TechCrunch, 2026-02-01): https://techcrunch.com/2026/02/01/india-offers-zero-taxes-through-2047-to-lure-global-ai-workloads/
monitoring_signals: Indian Ministry of Finance/MeitY notifications and budget follow-ons
Gazette of India publications referencing AI/data centers/compute incentives
Industry association commentary (NASSCOM) on implementing rules
Major hyperscaler statements contingent on policy details
predictions.rationale: Announced incentives often require detailed implementing rules; timeline risk is high due to inter-ministry coordination and fiscal tradeoffs.

predictions.text: A U.S. House committee (any standing committee) will publicly request documents or open an inquiry explicitly referencing foreign (e.g., UAE-linked) investment in the Trump family crypto venture 'World Liberty' (or equivalent named entity), by 2026-09-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a House committee publishes a letter, press release, or hearing notice explicitly citing UAE-linked/foreign investment in World Liberty (or the named venture) as an inquiry subject by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: UAE-linked investor quietly took a stake in Trump family crypto venture (NYT, 2026-02-01): https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/01/us/politics/trump-crypto-uae-world-liberty.html
monitoring_signals: House committee press releases and member letters
FEC/ethics-related public filings and watchdog reports
Media follow-ups naming investors and transaction details
DOJ/FinCEN/OFAC public actions that could spur congressional interest
predictions.rationale: Politically connected foreign-investment narratives often trigger oversight activity, but committee agendas and partisan control determine whether it formalizes.

predictions.text: The European Union will adopt a new Russia-related sanctions package (Council decision/regulation) that adds at least 50 new listings (persons and/or entities combined) by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the EU Official Journal publishes a Russia sanctions update/package by the deadline with >=50 newly listed persons/entities versus the prior consolidated list; otherwise NO.
evidence: Russia struck Ukraine’s energy sector; continued infrastructure attacks keep escalation risks elevated (NYT, 2026-02-01): https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/01/world/europe/russia-strikes-ukraine-energy-sector-killing-12-miners.html
monitoring_signals: EU Council agenda items and press briefings on Russia sanctions
EU Official Journal sanctions publications
Member-state statements (e.g., Germany/France/Poland) pushing new measures
G7 coordination communiqués
predictions.rationale: EU sanctions updates have been frequent; the threshold is mostly about package size and political cohesion rather than whether any action occurs.

predictions.text: WHO will publish a public Disease Outbreak News (DON) item, technical brief, or press briefing note explicitly referencing the newly reported bat virus infecting humans (as described in January 2026 reporting), by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a WHO web publication/briefing explicitly mentions the specific newly reported bat virus infecting humans (by name or unambiguous description tied to the report) by the deadline; otherwise NO.
evidence: Researchers report a hidden bat virus infecting humans (ScienceDaily, 2026-01-31): https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2026/01/260131084131.htm
monitoring_signals: WHO DON RSS feed and Emergencies updates
ProMED/HealthMap alerts and national public health advisories
Follow-on peer-reviewed publications clarifying transmissibility/severity
Genomic surveillance releases (GISAID/NCBI) and case clusters
predictions.rationale: WHO coverage depends on evidence of spread/severity and member-state reporting; many spillover reports do not trigger WHO DON unless broader risk emerges.
